title: Springtime for Bureaucrats
sub_head: A new report on our well-paid federal workforce.
body:
The Biden spending splurge has hardly begun and already federal employees must be feeling flush relative to their private counterparts.
Ralph Smith covers pay and benefits for federal employees at a website called FedSmith.com. Mr. Smith reports on the pay of the nearly 2.2 million federal workers classified as General Schedule employees:
Back in May 2020 the U.S. Labor Department’s Bureau of Labor Statistics found that the average annual wage across all occupations in the U.S. was just $56,310.
In fairness, this is not an exact apples-to-apples comparison because the federal workforce is very different from the one that supports it. A 2017 report from the Congressional Budget Office notes, “On the whole, federal workers tend to be older, more educated, and more concentrated in professional occupations than private-sector workers.”
Theoretically, we pay this class of lawyers and other highly credentialed public servants to use its precious expertise in myriad ways to enhance our lives. But even if one believes in the theory and in the value of federal expertise, it seems that we still end up overpaying.
